column4: Try to boot your own computer using the same flash drive. The flash drive may have been wrongly created. Sometimes I must recreate a flash drive to make it work as it should booting Ubuntu.

I have had the problem severl times. One time it was due to a graphics setting in BIOS (a "Vista thing") and other times I think it has to du with the graphics card of the computer you are trying to boot into.
one more point, my friend's laptop is very recent, could it be some new drivers?
is it a USB-related thing, or would the same behavior occur with a live cd?

Yes, it problably could. I hav ehad problems getting Ubuntu to work on a very new laptop, but I don't really know what the problem is. You could of course google the laptop model and Ubuntu problem. Some other persons may have had the same problem as you do
What is the model of the laptop?
thank you :) it's a new toshiba
but I don't know the exact model cause the laptop isn't mine and I don't have it right now
You could try to boot from another USB port. I suppose the computer has got more than one USB-port. Try another one just to be sure.
good point, haven't thought of it

It may be due to the USB ports. A friend had a laptop that didn't handla his cam but the cam worked just fine at my computer using the exactly same version of Ubuntu and the cam worked on his computer using Windows.
great, will try all these suggestions as soon as I get my hands on this laptop again :D
I don't if it does work but it may be worth a try at least. The booting problem be due to a lot of things I think.
Maybe you shall try booting a Live CD from cdrom too just to be sure.
If neither USB or CD works then I think it has do to the graphics card or the setting of it in BIOS.

There are also a lot of possibilities to change the way Ubuntu shall boot from the Live CD menu, but I don't really know the options. You can't set some different options at te Live Cd menu that change how Ubuntu Live shall try to boot.
